subject: accountancy
title: Basic Accounting Terms
notes: Complete real MCQ bank (100 questions) for Basic Accounting Terms for JKSSB Finance Accounts Assistant.
Includes basic, moderate and advanced questions with explanations.

questions.text: Which of the following is an asset?
questions.explanation: Debtors represent receivables and are treated as assets of the business.

questions.text: Which of the following is a liability?
questions.explanation: Bills Payable is an obligation to pay in future, hence a liability.

questions.text: Capital represents:
questions.explanation: Capital is the owner’s investment or equity in the business.

questions.text: Goods purchased for resale are known as:
questions.explanation: Goods purchased with the intention of resale are called purchases.

questions.text: Cash withdrawn by owner for personal use is called:
questions.explanation: When the owner withdraws cash or goods for personal use, it is called drawings.

questions.text: An increase in assets generally indicates:
questions.explanation: Increase in assets normally strengthens the financial position or may result from profits.

questions.text: Salary outstanding is classified as:
questions.explanation: Outstanding salary is a payment due to employees, so it is a liability.

questions.text: Prepaid insurance is a:
questions.explanation: Prepaid insurance is a payment made in advance and gives future benefit, hence an asset.

questions.text: Wages paid for installation of machinery is treated as:
questions.explanation: Cost of installation is added to machinery cost, hence capital expenditure.

questions.text: Rent received is classified as:
questions.explanation: Rent received is an income for the business.

questions.text: Trade discount is:

options.a: Recorded in the books of accounts
options.b: Not recorded in the books of accounts
options.c: Recorded in the cash book only

questions.explanation: Trade discount is deducted before recording the transaction; it is not recorded separately.

questions.text: Cash discount is:

options.b: Recorded in the books as discount allowed/received

questions.explanation: Cash discount is allowed/received on prompt payment and is recorded as an expense or income.

questions.text: Goods sold on credit increases:
questions.explanation: On credit sales, the amount becomes receivable from customers, increasing debtors.

questions.text: Something of value owned by a business is called:
questions.explanation: Anything owned by the business which has value is an asset.

questions.text: Loss of value of an asset due to wear and tear is called:
questions.explanation: Reduction in value of tangible fixed assets due to use is called depreciation.

questions.text: Cash received from sale of old furniture is usually treated as:
questions.explanation: Sale of fixed asset is a capital transaction, so receipt is capital in nature.

questions.text: Commission received is shown as:

options.a: Expense in profit and loss account
options.b: Income in profit and loss account

questions.explanation: Commission received is an income and appears on credit side of profit and loss account.

questions.text: Assets – Liabilities = ?
questions.explanation: According to the accounting equation, Capital = Assets – Liabilities.

questions.text: Credit purchases increase:
questions.explanation: On credit purchases, the amount is payable to suppliers, increasing creditors.

questions.text: Fixed assets are held for:
questions.explanation: Fixed assets are acquired for long-term use in business, not for resale.

questions.text: Unearned income is treated as:
questions.explanation: Unearned income (income received in advance) is a liability until service is rendered.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an asset?
questions.explanation: Outstanding rent is an amount payable, so it is a liability, not an asset.

questions.text: Goodwill is classified as:
questions.explanation: Goodwill has no physical form but has value, hence an intangible asset.

questions.text: Carriage inward is:
questions.explanation: Carriage inward is directly related to bringing goods to business and is a direct expense.

questions.text: Carriage outward is generally treated as:
questions.explanation: Carriage outward relates to delivery to customers and is an indirect selling expense.

questions.text: Outstanding expenses appear under which head in the balance sheet?
questions.explanation: Outstanding expenses are obligations to pay in future, hence current liabilities.

questions.text: Which transaction increases both an asset and a liability?
questions.explanation: Credit purchase increases stock (asset) and creditors (liability).

questions.text: Which of the following decreases capital?
questions.explanation: Drawings reduce the owner’s equity or capital in the business.

questions.text: Which one is a nominal account?
questions.explanation: Rent is an expense and is classified as a nominal account.

questions.text: Loss of stock due to fire is generally treated as:
questions.explanation: Loss of stock is a loss from normal business operations, so it is a revenue loss.

questions.text: Consignment stock is recorded in the books of:
questions.explanation: Consignment stock legally belongs to consignor and appears in his books.

questions.text: Capital + Liabilities = ?
questions.explanation: According to accounting equation: Assets = Capital + Liabilities.

questions.text: Bank overdraft is shown as:
questions.explanation: Bank overdraft is an amount payable to bank, hence a liability.

questions.text: Furniture used in business is:
questions.explanation: Furniture used in business operations is a fixed asset.

questions.text: Which of the following is a real account?
questions.explanation: Building account relates to property and is a real account.

questions.text: Which of the following is a fictitious asset?
questions.explanation: Preliminary expenses are written off over years and are shown as fictitious assets.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a current asset?
questions.explanation: Land is a fixed asset, not a current asset.

questions.text: Sales return (return inward) reduces:
questions.explanation: Sales return reduces the amount receivable from debtors.

questions.text: Purchase return (return outward) reduces:
questions.explanation: Purchase return reduces the amount payable to creditors.

questions.text: Which account follows the rule 'Debit what comes in, credit what goes out'?
questions.explanation: Real accounts follow the rule 'Debit what comes in, credit what goes out'.

questions.text: Discount received from creditors is classified as:
questions.explanation: Discount received is a gain or income for the business.

questions.text: Discount allowed to debtors is treated as:
questions.explanation: Discount allowed is a loss/expense to the business.

questions.text: Unearned income (income received in advance) is:
questions.explanation: Unearned income is an obligation to provide service/goods, so it is a liability.

questions.text: Capital expenditure generally results in:
questions.explanation: Capital expenditure gives benefit for more than one accounting period.

questions.text: Revenue expenditure is usually:

options.d: Not charged to profit and loss account

questions.explanation: Revenue expenditure occurs regularly and is charged to profit and loss account.

questions.text: Trade payables refer to:
questions.explanation: Trade payables are creditors to whom the firm owes money for credit purchases.

questions.text: Trade receivables refer to:
questions.explanation: Trade receivables include debtors who owe money to the business.

questions.text: Which one of the following is an intangible asset?
questions.explanation: Patent has no physical existence but provides legal rights, so it is intangible.

questions.text: Commission paid is classified as:
questions.explanation: Commission paid is an expense for the business.

questions.text: Goodwill generally arises due to:
questions.explanation: Goodwill arises from reputation, loyal customers and higher earning capacity.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT included in Cost of Goods Sold (COGS)?
questions.explanation: Carriage outward is a selling expense and not part of cost of goods sold.

questions.text: Which is NOT a feature of capital receipts?
questions.explanation: Day-to-day operational receipts are revenue receipts, not capital receipts.

questions.text: Deferred revenue expenditure is:

options.a: Written off fully in the same year
options.b: Written off over a number of years

questions.explanation: Deferred revenue expenditure is spread over several years due to its long-term benefit.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an example of a fictitious asset?
questions.explanation: Goodwill is an intangible asset, not a fictitious asset.

questions.text: Which of the following increases both capital and assets?
questions.explanation: Profit increases the capital and usually increases assets like cash or debtors.

questions.text: Loss on sale of machinery is classified as:
questions.explanation: Loss arising on sale of fixed assets is treated as capital loss.

questions.text: Which of the following equations always holds true?
questions.explanation: The fundamental accounting equation is Capital = Assets – Liabilities.

questions.text: Return inward appears in which account?
questions.explanation: Return inward reduces sales and appears on the debit side of the trading account.

questions.text: Return outward is first recorded in:
questions.explanation: Return outward (purchase return) is recorded in the purchases return book.

questions.text: Goodwill in the balance sheet is shown under:
questions.explanation: Goodwill is a type of fixed intangible asset.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an adjusting item?
questions.explanation: Trial balance difference is an error issue, not a standard adjustment item.

questions.text: A liability which is payable after a long period is called:
questions.explanation: A liability payable after more than a year is generally referred to as long-term liability.

questions.text: Expenditure incurred to maintain fixed assets in working condition is:
questions.explanation: Maintenance expenditure does not increase the asset’s capacity, so it is revenue in nature.

questions.text: Expenditure incurred to increase the earning capacity or life of a fixed asset is:
questions.explanation: Such expenditure brings long-term benefit and is capital in nature.

questions.text: Who is called a creditor?

options.b: A person to whom money is owed

questions.explanation: A creditor is the person to whom we owe money.

questions.text: Who is called a debtor?

options.a: A person who owes money to the business
options.b: A person to whom the business owes money

questions.explanation: Debtor is the person who has to pay money to the business.

questions.text: Commission earned but not yet received is termed as:
questions.explanation: Commission earned but not received is accrued income and treated as an asset.

questions.text: Which account is debited when bad debts are written off?
questions.explanation: Bad debts are transferred to bad debts account as an expense.

questions.text: If a liability increases and there is no change in capital, which must happen?
questions.explanation: To keep the equation balanced, increase in liability without change in capital means increase in assets.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a real account?
questions.explanation: Rent account is a nominal account, not real.

questions.text: Prepaid rent at the end of the year is shown as:

options.a: Expense in profit and loss account
options.b: Income in profit and loss account

questions.explanation: Prepaid rent represents benefit of future period, so it is shown as an asset.

questions.text: Accrued salary is treated as:
questions.explanation: Accrued salary (salary due but not paid) is a liability.

questions.text: Pre-received commission is an example of:
questions.explanation: Commission received in advance is a liability until it is earned.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of capital profit?

options.a: Profit on sale of fixed assets

questions.explanation: Profit from sale of fixed assets is capital profit.

questions.text: Goods given as charity are treated as:
questions.explanation: Goods distributed as charity are treated as an expense.

questions.text: Goods given as free samples are debited to:
questions.explanation: Goods given as samples to promote sales are treated as advertisement expense.

questions.text: Advance tax paid is shown as:
questions.explanation: Advance tax paid is an asset until adjusted against tax liability.

questions.text: If liabilities decrease and assets remain same, capital will:
questions.explanation: Decrease in liabilities with same assets means net worth (capital) increases.

questions.text: Which item increases owner’s equity?
questions.explanation: When owner introduces more capital, owner’s equity increases.

questions.text: Goods destroyed by fire are treated as:
questions.explanation: Loss of goods is usually revenue loss as it relates to trading stock.

questions.text: Which is an example of a contra-asset account?
questions.explanation: Provision for doubtful debts reduces the value of debtors and is a contra-asset.

questions.text: Accrued income is shown as:
questions.explanation: Accrued income is income earned but not received, treated as asset.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a liability?
questions.explanation: Prepaid telephone bill is an asset, not a liability.

questions.text: Goods withdrawn by owner for personal use are:
questions.explanation: Goods taken by owner for personal use are drawings and reduce capital.

questions.text: Bank charges debited by bank are treated as:
questions.explanation: Bank charges are an expense to the business.

questions.text: Double entry system means each transaction affects:

options.b: At least one debit and one credit account

questions.explanation: Under double entry, every transaction has a dual aspect and affects at least two accounts.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an asset?
questions.explanation: Outstanding commission (commission payable) is a liability, not an asset.

questions.text: Income received in advance is classified as:
questions.explanation: Income received in advance is a liability until the related service is rendered.

questions.text: Which of the following is a capital expenditure?
questions.explanation: Installation charges are added to asset cost and are capital in nature.

questions.text: Goods purchased for cash will:
questions.explanation: Cash purchases result in an increase in purchases and decrease in cash.

questions.text: Goods sold on credit will:
questions.explanation: On credit sale, sales (income) and debtors (asset) increase.

questions.text: Loss of asset by theft is treated as:
questions.explanation: Loss by theft of a fixed asset is capital loss.

questions.text: Unearned revenue is shown under:
questions.explanation: Unearned revenue is a current liability as it is payable in form of service/goods.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a generally used category of asset?
questions.explanation: Fictitious assets are not real assets; they are deferred revenue expenditures.

questions.text: Accrued commission is shown as:

options.a: Expense in profit and loss account

questions.explanation: Accrued commission is income earned but not received, so it is an asset.

questions.text: A person who gives loan to the business is:
questions.explanation: A lender to the business is also its creditor.

questions.text: Which of the following is a real account?
questions.explanation: Furniture relates to a tangible asset and is a real account.

questions.text: Profit earned during the year will:
questions.explanation: Profit increases the owner’s capital or equity.

questions.text: Bad debts written off will reduce:
questions.explanation: Bad debts reduce the amount receivable from debtors.

questions.text: Loss in business at the end of the year is:
questions.explanation: Loss reduces the owner’s capital and is deducted from capital in balance sheet.
